abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Cotton Sector
            Development Project in Togo are as follows: overall outcome
            of the project are rated as satisfactory, the Bank
            performance was rated mixed, and the performance of the
            Borrower was rated satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned
            from the project are: 1) the need to have a close
            coordination between macro-level reforms and sectoral
            investment projects in order to maximize the impact of
            investments. The close link with Economic Recovery Project
            (ERAC) was instrumental in Government's acceptance of
            the liberalization of cotton export marketing; (b) a
            mid-term review is an essential instrument to gauge not only
            the effectiveness of project implementation, but also the
            need to validate project objectives and redesign its
            approaches and activities to take into account changing
            circumstances. In the case of this project, no mid-term
            review was carried out. However, the project's
            objectives, as interpreted by Bank staff and Government
            officials, slowly evolved from an emphasis on production and
            efficiencies to institutional reform. The lack of a mid-term
            review and project redesign had no impact on the final
            outcome, but it could have been an appropriate forum to
            highlight slow progress in key areas; and (c) institutional
            reforms requires time to build consensus and be implemented,
            and their impact is generally slower than expected. This
            needs to be factored into project design and the expected
            benefit stream.
